awd_titl_txt: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2021 ACM CCS
awd_abstract_narration:
The annual ACM Conference on Computer and Communications Security (ACM CCS) is a leading international forum for the timely dissemination of cutting-edge research results in computer and communications security. The conference achieves that by bringing together researchers, practitioners, developers, and users to participate in several technical sessions, tutorials, poster sessions, panels, and workshops. The program of the main conference consists of approximately 140 technical research papers across a wide range of topics in the domain of computer networks security and online privacy. Participation in the conference is a valuable opportunity for students and is an important and integral part in their cybersecurity graduate education. 

This award provides travel support to encourage participation in the 2021 ACM CCS by students who would normally find it difficult to attend. Criteria for selection include evidence of a serious interest in the field as demonstrated by statement of research, curriculum vitae showing research output, coursework and/or project experience. Organizers encourage participation of women and students from other under-represented groups in computing. Preference is given to undergraduate students participating in the poster session, and students with papers in the conference or one of the conference’s co-located workshops who do not have other financial support to attend the conference.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

inst.inst_name: The University of Central Florida Board of Trustees
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE UNIVERSITY OF CENTRAL FLORIDA BOARD OF TRUSTEES

por.por_cntn:
In 2022, ACM CCS was held in person in Los Angeles, CA, November 7-11. To broaden the participation of students in the conference, the travel chairs limited the selection of awardees to students who do not have papers in the conference, focusing on improving the attendance of females and other represented minorities. Students were asked to submit a CV and a statement highlighting the desired objectives of attending the conference. Of the 21 recipients selected and awarded the award in 2022 (6 females and 15 males), 18 accepted the award (4 females and 14 males). The 18 students came from 14 universities located in 10 different states. All of the awarded students were graduate students, and none of the awardees were presenting authors, fulfilling the promise of the grant in enabling a broader participation of students in this leading venue.

In 2021, and despite the initial intent and effort to have ACM CCS held in person, it was finally decided to have the conference done virtually, given the travel restrictions to South Korea in November 2021, which included self-quarantine for one week. To broaden the participation of students in the conference, the travel chairs limited the selection of awardees to students who do not have papers in the conference, focusing on improving the attendance of females and other represented minorities. Students were asked to submit a CV and a statement highlighting the desired objectives of attending the conference. Based on a pool of 76 students, selected 43 awardees to receive a registration waiver in order to attend the conference virtually. 15 (35%) of the awardees identified as females, while 28 (65%) of the awardees identified as male. The awardees come from 26 different institutions, 4 of which are R2 universities while the rest are R1 universities. Besides gender and background diversity, the committee considered geographical diversity, where the students came from 16 states.


Last Modified: 07/10/2023
Modified by: David Mohaisen
